question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Let
\[\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}.\]Compute $\mathbf{A}^{100}.$
inference:
We can compute the first few powers of $\mathbf{A}$:
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \\
\mathbf{A}^3 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I},
\end{align*}where $\mathbf{I}$ is the identity matrix.  Hence, $\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A},$ $\mathbf{A}^5 = \mathbf{A}^2,$ and so on.  In general,
\[\mathbf{A}^n = \begin{cases}
\mathbf{I} & \text{if $n$ is a multiple of 3}, \\
\mathbf{A} & \text{if $n$ leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 3}, \\
\mathbf{A}^2 & \text{if $n$ leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by 3}.
\end{cases}\]Since 100 leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 3,
\[\mathbf{A}^{100} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}.$ I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
We compute the first few powers of $\mathbf{A}$:
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \\
\mathbf{A}^3 &= \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Then
\[\mathbf{A}^{100} = (\mathbf{A}^3)^{33} \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{A} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]

question:

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \\
\mathbf{A}^3 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I},
\end{align*}where $\mathbf{I}$ is the identity matrix.  Hence, $\mathbf{A}^4 = \mathbf{A},$ $\mathbf{A}^5 = \mathbf{A}^2,$ and so on.  In general,
\[\mathbf{A}^n = \begin{cases}
\mathbf{I} & \text{if $n$ is a multiple of 3}, \\
\mathbf{A} & \text{if $n$ leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 3}, \\
\mathbf{A}^2 & \text{if $n$ leaves a remainder of 2 when divided by 3}.
\end{cases}\]Since 100 leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 3,
\[\mathbf{A}^{100} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]Final Answer: $\boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}.$ I hope it is correct.

ground_truth:
We compute the first few powers of $\mathbf{A}$:
\begin{align*}
\mathbf{A}^2 &= \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix}, \\
\mathbf{A}^3 &= \mathbf{A} \mathbf{A}^2 = \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{pmatrix} = \mathbf{I}.
\end{align*}Then
\[\mathbf{A}^{100} = (\mathbf{A}^3)^{33} \mathbf{A} = \mathbf{A} = \boxed{\begin{pmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1 \\ 1 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \end{pmatrix}}.\]
